title: MedFuncta: Modality-Agnostic Representations Based on Efficient Neural Fields
author: Paul Friedrich (Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Basel), Florentin Bieder (Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Basel), Philippe Cattin (Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Basel)
relevance_why: The work introduces a method to create modality-agnostic representations which can be beneficial for tasks like audio manipulation and generation, paralleling Haohe's focus on audio processing.
background: Creating representations of medical signals across various modalities using neural fields, allowing for continuous encoding rather than traditional grid-based methods.
contribution: MedFuncta introduces a modality-agnostic continuous data representation using neural fields to solve the challenges of high computational load and poor scaling with grid resolution, achieving improved reconstruction quality and convergence speed.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods predominantly used grid-based representations which limit scalability and overlook continuous data structures.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by utilizing meta-learning approaches and an adaptive frequency schedule that enhances representation accuracy without requiring high computational cost.

key_innovation: The introduction of a frequency schedule to address spectral bias in commonly used activation functions, which improves both training speed and reconstruction quality.
real_world_impact: This work has the potential to advance medical imaging analysis and offers a framework that could be adapted for audio applications, such as improving audio synthesis through continuous representations.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned in the provided text.

new_terms.neural fields: **Neural fields** are a representation technique where data is treated as a continuous function, allowing for flexible and high-resolution data encoding.
new_terms.spectral bias: **Spectral bias** refers to the phenomenon where a neural network tends to learn low-frequency patterns of signals before capturing high-frequency details, potentially hindering learning efficiency.

open_sourcing: Code is publicly available at https://github.com/pfriedri/medfuncta
